text:
They had muzzled a student.


UA, the top hero school in the nation, known for being a pillar of morality, had muzzled a student. And not just any student: Bakugou, one of the star hero students and winner of the sports festival was currently chained to a pillar and muzzled, hard metal boxes attached to his hands to keep him from blowing anyone up. 


Below, in the crowd of onlookers, Shinsou watched in horror, though he kept his expression blank. His stomach had sunk like a lead balloon, his mouth going dry and his hands shaking. The barely there, pale white scars that marked just across the tops of his cheeks and across the bridge of his nose seemed to burn at the memory of all the times he had been muzzled, the straps cinched so tight that the metal split the fragile skin on his face.


“Wow, can you believe that?” one of his classmates whispered to another, the pair looking at Bakugou with disgusted expressions. 


“I know, it's insane.”


And for a moment, Shinsou felt a burst of hope. Maybe, just maybe, someone was going to speak up. They would say how wrong it was for Bakugou to be treated like this. That 

no one

 should be treated like this. And then, his classmate finished the sentence.


“He’s acting like a wild animal. Can’t blame the teachers for being cautious like that.”


“The kid is hardly heroic. I’m surprised they haven’t done this sooner.”


Without a word, Shinsou turned and left, taking long and fast steps straight to the bathroom, where he promptly locked himself in a stall. His knees buckled and his head hung over the porcelain toilet as he heaved, throwing up everything that he had eaten that day. 


UA had muzzled Bakugou. No one seemed to care.


If it was okay to muzzle Bakugou, a high ranking hero student, then it was only a matter of time before they came for the dangerous gen-ed kid with a villain’s quirk. 


He had to make sure that didn’t happen. He 

couldn’t

 let that happen. 


---


The following Monday, when classes started back up again, Shinsou came to UA with a plan. 


The first step was to talk to one of the sports festival winners. He had to know 

why

 Bakugou was muzzled. Obviously, it was partially to do with how he acted, but what set him off? Had he tried to attack a teacher? Illegal quirk usage? There had to be an answer.


Asking Todoroki wasn’t an option. The guy was standoffish and cold, even on his best days, and typically had a lot of eyes on him. People would notice if Shinsou spoke to him. Bakugou was aggressive and pretty full of himself, so if Shinsou asked him, it was a fifty-fifty chance that he would either get an explosion to the face or be told to fuck off, if not both. That left Tokoyami. He was quiet and kept to himself, meaning he wasn’t normally around crowds. He was a bit of a loner, so he probably wouldn’t appreciate Shinsou talking to him, but he wasn’t likely to attack Shinsou. He was Shinsou’s best bet of finding out what happened. 


So Shinsou waited. He waited until lunch and scanned the cafeteria, as he did every time he came in there, searching for threats. Only this time, he did a second scan, looking for Tokoyami. 


He wasn’t hard to find, tucked away in the back of the cafeteria. He was alone, at least for now, since most of Class 1-A was still in line for lunch. Tokoyami seemed to have packed himself a meal, and was peacefully opening his bento to enjoy it. 


Without money for lunch, Shinsou didn’t bother getting into the line. He sidestepped his classmates and made a beeline directly for Tokoyami. As he approached, Tokoyami looked up. His quirk, Dark Shadow, peaked out over his shoulder, bright yellow eyes watching Shinsou’s every move.


“May I help you?” Tokoyami asked, deep voice hard and cold.


Shinsou nodded. Carefully, he worded his question in such a way that it wasn’t really a question, just as he did with everyone else he spoke to. “I want to know why Bakugou was chained and muzzled. You were one of the only people up there with him.”


Tokoyami raised one of his brows questioningly. 


“Why do you want to know that?”


“I know some people who are concerned,” Shinsou lied. “They don’t want to repeat Bakugou’s mistakes. I won’t be telling them directly what he did, only what they should not do. I’m not one to spread rumors.”


Dark Shadow glanced between Tokoyami and Shinsou before coming out further, clawed hands gently touching Tokoyami’s shoulders. 


“He didn’t want the medal.”


“Dark Shadow! Hush!”


“It's not a big deal, Fumi. It's not like anyone else would do what he did,” Dark Shadow said with a pout before looking back at Shinsou. “He didn’t feel like he deserved it so he tried to refuse the award. He kept telling them no and trying to leave. Tried to push past them, acting kinda mean about it. Even set off his quirk a little I think. They decided to make him stay the only way that they could. Your friends probably don’t have anything to worry about. Bakugou is a rule breaker, so this was a long time coming.”


“It's not right to talk ill of our brethren,” Tokoyami scolded, pushing Dark Shadow back. 


Shinsou gave the pair a stilted bow as they started to bicker, cutting them off before it could get any worse. “Thank you. I will tell them they have nothing to worry about.”


As he walked away, Shinsou knew he definitely had something to worry about. Sure, he followed the rules for the most part. What kid doesn’t break a rule or two on occasion? But his record stated otherwise. He had a long list of detentions and suspensions, all dating back to early elementary school. It always went the same way, no matter what school he went to. Someone in his class would do something wrong, the teacher would start to lecture them, and then the kid would cry, saying that Shinsou made them do it with his quirk. The teachers never questioned it. After all, why wouldn’t they believe the sweet kid with the nice quirk? 


UA was supposed to be different. It was supposed to be safe here. But after seeing what happened at the sports festival, it was only a matter of time before everything went wrong again. 


And so, it was time for the next step of Shinsou’s plan: make himself as invisible as possible so everyone would just forget about him. He could disappear into the background, make himself as small and unnoticeable as possible. Then, the teachers would have no reason to muzzle him. Now that he knew what Bakugou did to get muzzled, he was already one step closer to being safe.


Shinsou just had to never ever say no to a teacher. They didn’t like it. Don’t refuse, follow the rules, and keep quiet. That’s what Shinsou had to do to be safe. It meant that any chance he had of making it into the hero course was shot, since next year at the sports festival, he would need to get eliminated in the first round to keep attention off of himself, but if it meant not having to wear that god awful muzzle, then it would be worth it. 


Once lunch was over, Shinsou walked quietly back to his classroom. He sat in his seat and kept his eyes downcast, diligently taking his notes. He didn’t raise his hand to answer or ask questions, and he kept himself curled and small at his desk. When the teacher asked him to help her move a heavy projector, he immediately agreed, not one word or sound of complaint slipping past his lips.


Quiet, small, agreeable, and unnoticable. 


He didn’t speak to another student until the very end of the day, when he was leaving the school to walk back to his foster home. Just past the gates, sitting on the edge of a curb and holding a small mirror to get a better look at his face was Bakugou. He was grimacing at his reflection, poking and prodding at a cut across the top of his cheekbone. 


A cut made by the muzzle.


Shinsou was speaking before he even realized he had opened his mouth.


“Hydrogen peroxide.”


Bakugou startled, looking up at him and clutching the mirror tight to his chest.


“Huh?”


“Hydrogen peroxide,” Shinsou repeated, gesturing to the cut. “It’ll clean the cut and it's cheap to get. Tape some gauze over it and don’t pull the scab off. Should help keep it from scarring.”


“What the fuck do you know about that shit?” Bakugou snapped, standing from the curb and crowding Shinsou, a snarl on his face as he stood barely an inch from the taller boy. Shinsou took a half step back, startled, only to freeze as Bakugou’s expression changed. 


Bakugou’s eyes narrowed, moving across the thin scars on Shinsou’s cheeks and nose. After a silent moment, Bakugou slouched backwards, growling quietly to himself. 


“You’ve got your own,” he said quietly, glancing around.


Shinsou nodded, watching Bakugou warily. “I do. You’ll tell someone.”


“Tch. Like I have time to be talking about you.” Bakugou turned to leave, his shoulders hunched near his ears as he started to walk away. After a few steps, he paused, just barely turning his head to speak to Shinsou again. “You said hydrogen peroxide?”


“Yeah. It's going to sting but it works.”


Bakugou nodded and continued his walk. Heaving a sigh, Shinsou started off home, trying to ignore the sinking feeling that he made a mistake talking to Bakugou. 


When he reached the foster home he was currently staying in, he opened the door as quietly as he could, silently praying that the hinges wouldn’t squeak. Kicking his shoes off, he made his way further into the house. 


The four younger kids, a set of identical twin boys and their slightly older sisters, were watching TV, all huddled together on the couch. Another boy, who was a few years younger than Shinsou, was at the dining room table working on his homework while his sister, just a year older than him, was in the kitchen working on dinner. 


Shinsou silently went to the room he shared with the other boys and slid his backpack under his bed. Padding back downstairs, he went to the kitchen and gestured for the girl to go join her brother. She did so immediately, avoiding eye contact and scurrying away to leave Shinsou to finish cooking. 


Eventually their foster parents came home. And just like every other night, the wife chain smoked into the late hours while her husband drank himself into a stupor. No one spoke to Shinsou, and like every other day, he carefully avoided speaking to anyone. 


Last time he spoke, simply telling everyone dinner was ready, his foster mother had shrieked, slapping him across the face and knocking him to the ground. His foster father forced the muzzle on him, grabbed him by his hair, and dragged him to the hall closet, where he was locked in for the night. Shinsou didn’t get food for two days after that.


He’d learned his lesson though: don’t speak inside the house.


“Apparently 1-A’s teacher finally got some of his bandages off,” one of Shinsou’s classmates said, skipping into the classroom excitedly. “His arms are still wrapped up but all of the bandages on his face are gone!”


“Does he look all messed up? I heard he got his face slammed into the ground by that thing that was as strong as All Might!” a boy asked, perking up in his seat.


The girl shook her head. “Nah, he’s just got, like, one scar under his eye. He looks way more tired than usual though.”


“I heard he’s been on a lot of medication. That’s why he was in the announcers box at the sports festival. They didn’t want him down near the fighting just in case he got hurt.”


“Too bad. Maybe he would have been able to keep Bakugou from going feral like he did.”


Someone else laughed, clearly agreeing. Before anyone else could say anything, their teacher walked in, signaling the start for class.


For the first time in a week, Shinsou raised his hand. “Sensei, I need to use the restroom.”


“Go ahead, Shinsou, just hurry back.”


Shinsou barely waited for her to finish her sentence before he was out of his seat. He barely made it to the bathroom before he wretched, spitting up bile from his empty stomach. Before he left the bathroom, he took a moment to rinse his mouth with water, clearing out the bitter taste from the back of his throat. 


He was half way back to his classroom when a deep voice stopped him in his tracks. 


“You’re the gen-ed kid that made it to the last event.”


Ice ran through Shinsou’s veins. 


He knew that voice. 


That was Eraserhead.


As in, the hero he had looked up to since he was a kid after he’d managed to spot the tail end of one of his arrests.


Keeping his eyes downcast, he turned around to face the heroics teacher. He gave a short nod.


“You went out when facing Midoriya, right?”


Shinsou nodded again. 


“You did well.”


That was startling enough to get Shinsou to look up, finally making eye contact with Eraserhead.


The man was tall, though only a few inches taller than Shinsou. His long black hair was messy, though it was stringy, like it hadn’t been washed recently. From what Shinsou had seen of the man, that was uncommon. Eraserhead did look more tired than usual, and a little scruffier, so if Shinsou had to guess, his injuries were taking a toll on him. The man’s arms were still wrapped but no longer in a sling. A shiny, slightly puckered scar marred his face, curving below his eye. Overall, he didn’t look bad for a guy who only a few weeks ago had been on death’s door. 


And here he was, Shinsou’s idol, telling him that he’d done well at the sports festival.


Eraserhead arched a single brow, acting almost amused. “You seem surprised.”


Shinsou swallowed thickly. “I… I didn’t win, sir.”


“No, you didn’t. Do you know why?”


“I wasn’t strong enough.”


Eraserhead nodded. “Correct. You weren’t. Not entirely your fault though. Gen-ed isn’t designed to train their students for fights like that. You could have trained on your own to build strength though. And you rely too heavily on your quirk. You need to think things through more, be more creative. After all, you don’t see me going out on the streets and only using my quirk to fight villains, do you?”


Shaking his head, Shinsou let his gaze fall to the ground again. He kept his breathing even, trying to fight back the urge to cry at the harsh, but true, words.


“You want to be a hero, don’t you? Are you serious about it?”


Shinsou took a deep breath. “Yes, sir. I want to be a hero. More than anything.” And then he waited. He waited for the barbed words telling him to give up on his dream. To quit while he was ahead. To choose something realistic. 


“Are you willing to put the work in?”


Silently, Shinsou nodded.


“Good. Meet me after school. I’ll train you.”


Shinsou gasped, whipping his head up to meet Eraserhead’s piercing gaze again.


“What?” Shinsou asked, and then promptly cringed at himself for asking the question. 


“I’ll train you. It’ll be hard. You’ll probably hate me most days. But if you put in the time and effort to learn, then I think you have a shot at transfering into the hero course. So meet me after school outside the teacher’s lounge. We won’t start the training today, since you’ll need to speak to your parents about staying late after school, but I will give you the training plans you’ll need to follow outside of school. It will include cardio, stretches, and a diet plan that you will have to follow to strengthen and protect your body. Will there be any problem with that?”


Yes. There absolutely would be a problem. First, Shinsou didn’t have the money to buy extra food, let alone the specific stuff that Eraserhead would tell him he needs to eat. Second, he probably wouldn’t have the time to do any of the cardio or stretches, since he was responsible for helping take care of the younger kids in the home. The second youngest, the oldest girl, helped him, so maybe he could strike a deal with her that he would take care of packing all the lunches the night before if she would make dinner and watch everyone until he got home… Shinsou would have to be sure to be back before his foster parents though, since there was no way they would agree to letting him do this. He would have to stay up later at night, since he typically did his homework while he cooked dinner or while the other kids were using the shower, but he didn’t sleep much as it was, so that probably wasn’t a huge deal. 


None of that mattered though. Shinsou couldn’t tell his teacher no. Kids that said no to their teachers were labeled bad kids. Bad kids got muzzled.


“Yes sir, I can do that.”


Eraserhead nodded. “Good. Meet me after school. Hurry back to class now, you don’t want to get in trouble.”


Shinsou didn’t have to be told twice. Without missing a beat, he scurried down the hall, making it back to his classroom in record time. It wasn’t until he was back in his seat that it sunk in. 



Eraserhead was going to teach him how to be a hero

.


---


Back at his foster home, Shinsou waited until the younger kids were getting ready for bed to pull his foster sister aside.


Kiyo was a quiet girl, only 13 but mature beyond her age. Like the rest of the members of the household, Kiyo didn’t speak to Shinsou, though it didn’t seem malicious. It was a rule in the house that no one was to speak to Shinsou, and so she followed it. Taping at her shoulder, he gestured for her to follow him to the bathroom. When she seemed hesitant, he held up the notepad he’d brought with him that read ‘

I need to talk to you. I’ll write everything down so I won’t speak.

’


Kiyo nodded, though she still seemed nervous when she followed him. 


Standing in the bathroom, Shinsou wrote out another note to her.


‘

I am going to be taking extra lessons after school starting next week. I’ll be sure to be here before Mr. and Mrs. Ikeda get home but I won’t be back in time to help make dinner. Could you do it and cover for me so I don’t get in trouble?

’


“Why do you need extra lessons?” Kiyo asked, nervousness creeping into her voice. “Are you doing bad at school? If they find out…”


Shinsou quickly shook his head and started to write again. ‘

No, it's extra lessons to help me get ahead. It's because I’m doing well that I get to do this. Please? I can make everyone’s lunches the night before while everyone is asleep, that way you don’t have to do it in the mornings. And then I can make breakfast for the little ones too.’

 He didn’t bother writing that he would make breakfast for himself and the older kids. They never ate breakfast, instead passing their measly shares to the younger children. 


Kiyo bit her lip, worrying it between her teeth. “What do I tell the other kids?”


‘

Just say I’m tutoring someone. That way, if it does get back to the Ikedas, I can say that it's just until midterms or finals or whatever and then arrange to stop the extra lessons.

’


After another moment of internal debate, Kiyo finally nodded.


Shinsou smiled widely at her. ‘

Thank you! I promise I’ll make it up to you.

’


“Just don’t get caught, okay? I know we aren’t close or anything, but I still don’t like seeing them hurt you. It makes the little kids cry.”


With one final nod, Shinsou slipped past her and out of the bathroom.


For once in his life, it felt like things were starting to look up.


---


“Oi! Troll Doll!” a rough voice shouted, startling Shinsou from his thoughts. 


He’d actually had a little money for lunch today and had taken his food outside to eat. Most people stayed in, since it was starting to get pretty warm out, making it the perfect place for Shinsou to go to hide away. 


Looking up, he found Bakugou storming across the grounds towards him and the tree he’d been sitting under. Shinsou looked around, trying to figure out who Bakugou was speaking to.


“I’m talking to you, dumbass!”


Well, that answered that question.


“What are you doing out here, fuck-face?” Bakugou growled, stopping in front of Shinsou and giving his small meal a disgusted look. 


“Eating lunch, obviously.” 


“Yeah, but you’re outside.”


“It's quiet here.”


He made a none committal noise and then dropped to sit beside Shinsou. “You’re weird.”


“You’re one to talk.”


Bakugou actually snorted at that, one corner of his lip quirking up. After a moment of the pair sitting in silence, Bakugou finally spoke again.


“My parents didn’t give a shit,” he said, his voice quiet. “They saw me on TV. They saw the cut. They saw me bandage it. They didn’t say anything. You’re the only one who has. Why?”


“You already know why,” Shinsou said, taking another bite of his lunch.


“What, because you got muzzled before you think you know better than me? You think you’re tougher or something? Come on, zombie eyes, lets fucking fight! I’ll show you who's stronger!”


Shinsou pulled away, looking at him with a mix of fear and confusion. “What the fuck, no, I don’t want to fight. I saw you and I was worried. You didn’t look like you’d ever been muzzled before so figured I’d give you some advice.”


“How could you tell I hadn’t been muzzled?”


“You still tried to move your jaw.”


That caught Bakugou’s attention. He glanced over at Shinsou, watching the slightly taller boy pick at his food.


Shinsou continued. “I could see you up there, still trying to talk and yell. And then, when I saw the cut, it only confirmed to me that you tried to move your jaw. The muzzle wasn’t too tight on your face, so it shouldn’t have cut you. The only way it would do that is if you had been struggling against it. You learn after wearing them a few times not to fight against it.”


“Shit, you really do know about wearing those things. Your’s went over your nose too, didn’t it? The one they put on me didn’t.”


Shinsou nodded. “Yeah, the one you wore is higher end and newer. They don’t cover the noses on them any more because too many people suffocated. They’d be wearing them, panic, and then throw up inside of it. Since they were panicking, they’d be hyperventilating and inhale the vomit. It… it isn’t a nice way to go.”


“And they still made you wear one like that?”


“Only option available to them.”


Bakugou grimaced, ducking his head again. “How many times did you have to wear it?”


“Don’t know,” Shinsou said with a shrug. “A lot. It kinda followed me wherever I got sent. Foster care is bitch.”


“Shit, and I thought it was bad for me.”


“I mean, it was still bad for you. I could tell you were freaking out pretty hard.”


Bakugou snarled, a few small explosions popping across the palms of his hands. “I wasn’t scared! I was pissed!”


“Okay. Doesn’t mean you weren’t still losing your shit up there. I might not be the top student of my class, but I’m up there. I’m not stupid.”


He looked away again, avoiding Shinsou’s gaze. “It… It reminded me of something. That’s all.”


“Well, I’ve been dumping my tragic backstory on you. Only fair you do the same. Go on then,” Shinsou said, leaning back against the tree. When Bakugou didn’t move to speak, Shinsou huffed. “You don’t have to if you don’t want to, man, but I’m probably the least likely person in the school to judge you. I don’t give a shit and I don’t really talk to anyone, so I won’t be spreading the story around the school.”


Bakugou took a shuddering breath before opening his mouth. “I got attacked, right at the end of middle school. It was all over the news. This villain with a slime quirk grabbed me and tried to… tried to take over my body. He kept trying to force his way down my throat to suffocate me. Only reason I survived long enough for anyone to do anything was because I started setting off my quirk. It was enough to get the dude to back off a few times and let me grab some air. When they chained me up on the podium, with the muzzle on my face, it was like I was back there, grabbed by that villain. It felt like I couldn’t breathe, just like with the villain, even though the muzzle had holes and my nose was uncovered.”


“Oh fuck,” Shinsou said, eyebrows rising. “You had a flashback. Those are rough. I’ve had them a few times but it's been a while.”


“What do you do to make them stop?”


“I mostly avoid the things that cause them. If I’m in one, I keep reminding myself it isn't real and try to do breathing exercises. Doesn’t always work though. Sometimes, if I start to panic and it seems like I might have one, my body redirects it and makes me puke. Stops the whole thing in its tracks. Happened when I saw you in the muzzle and again when I heard people talking about it, actually.”


Bakugou snorted. “Aren’t you a big softie, feeling all bad for me. I don’t need your pity.”


“Don’t pity you, dude. Mostly I’m mad that none of the teachers put a stop to it.”


“Oh same. Like, what the fuck, all the teachers saw that and thought it was fine? That’s such bullshit.”


“Exactly!” Shinsou said, showing any sort of emotion in his voice for the first time in the whole conversation. “I thought UA was supposed to be different! They’re always saying how they won’t stand for bullying or quirk discrimination, and then the teachers go and chain a child! It makes no goddamn sense!”


“I didn’t even attack anyone. I was telling them I didn’t want the medal cuz I didn’t feel like I earned it and I accidentally set off a few little explosions. ” he snarled.

Aizawa’s scarf lashed out, catching the man’s arm and throwing him into a wall far away from the children. 


“What the fuck? Who the fuck are you?!” The man shouted, staggering to his feet.


“Sir, you are under arrest for child abuse,” one of the officer said, pulling a set of handcuffs from his belt. “If you would just come quietly, we can discuss everything at the station.”


The man lunged, swinging a large fist at the officer. Aizawa dodged in, blocking the wild punch and knocking the man to the ground. With a knee pressed firmly into the man’s back, he leaned down to whisper in his ear.


“You think it's fun beating on children? Starving them? Muzzling them? Does that make you feel tough? Have fun in prison, asshole. They’re just going to love someone like you.”


“Fuck you, asshole,” the man spat. “You talking about that villain freak? You should be locking him up, not me.”


“Is this about Shinsou?” the woman asked, finally speaking up. “He’s a liar! Always causing trouble!”


“That doesn’t change the fact that you hurt these children right in front of us. Let’s go,” one of the officers said, taking the woman’s arm, handcuffing her, and leading her out of the house. 


Aizawa hefted the man to his feet, taking the handcuffs to cuff him, and then dragged him to the police cruiser, kicking and screaming. Another officer stayed inside with the children, helping them to pack their things to move to their next foster homes. Once the man was put in the car, Aizawa grabbed the bags he brought and went inside to find Shinsou’s things.


The girl, the one who had opened the door, was standing in the living room, the injured boy clutched to her side and a bag for each of them at her feet. 


“Sir,” she quietly said, getting Aizawa’s attention. “Is Shinsou okay?”


Aizawa nodded. “Yes, he is. I made sure.”


“Thank you. I was getting worried. The Ikedas came home early and when they saw Shinsou wasn’t here, they got really angry. He’d said his extra lessons had stopped, so he’d be home right after school, so I didn’t know where he was.”’


“He’s safe,” Aizawa assured. “He told us what was happening here. He got help for all of you.”


The girl’s eyes welled up again, her bottom lip quivering. “Can you tell him I’m sorry? I never really talked to him because of the rules and I always felt bad. I don’t want him to think I did it because I didn’t like him.”


“I’m sure he already knows, but I’ll tell him. Can you show me where his things are? I’d like to collect them for him.”


She gestured for him to follow and brought him to a room that had two sets of bunkbeds. It wasn’t a large room, and with all the furniture packed in, it was even tighter. The girl took the suitcase from him and told him to stay outside the room, since the two smaller boys were still in there packing and Aizawa likely wouldn’t have fit.


She set the bag on one of the beds and began packing things into it. The clothes she grabbed were worn and old, the colors faded and holes mended. There were only a handful of items that looked like they held any sentimental value, which she carefully tucked in amongst the clothes to protect them. Shinsou’s school uniforms, which looked to be the newest things he owned, were then placed on top.


In all, his belongings only filled half the bag.


After making sure all the children were seen off to safer and more suitable homes, Aizawa made the trip back to his own, his shoulders drooping in exhaustion. Climbing the stairs to his apartment, all he could think about was how he’d failed. He’d missed all the signs with Shinsou and Bakugou. Bakugou, who reacted to his own abuse and neglect through anger to hide his fear. Who kept everyone at a distance, so that it would hurt less when they left him. Who had been treated as less than human on live TV and only one person had told him it was wrong. That person being Shinsou, who so clearly tried to please his teachers in an effort to protect himself. The fawn response, as Aizawa remembered it being called. Shinsou, the boy who kept as quiet as possible, did everything he was told to do, and never once complained, all in hopes of avoiding retaliation. No wonder the pair were so protective of each other: they complimented each other perfectly. Where Shinsou needed protection from peers and teachers, Bakugou could provide it. Where Bakugou needed help to get out of trouble, Shinsou could arrange it. 


Maybe Hizashi was right: Shinsou and Bakugou were a lot like them at that age. 


When Shinsou woke up, Aizawa had come back. He’d dragged in a suitcase filled with everything Shinsou owned, which Shinsou was thankful for, but also embarrassed about. It was bad enough that his teachers had seen him cry and had seen he was too weak to defend himself, but now they also knew he had so little. Aizawa explained that the other kids were safe, having been taken to reputable foster homes, and that Shinsou’s foster parents were in custody for child abuse. 


Shinsou nodded along with his explanation. “Where will I be going?”


“For now, you’ll stay here.”


“But I can’t stay here forever. Is there a group home or something nearby? Then I’ll still be able to get to UA.”


Mic came into the room, plates piled with food balanced on his arms. He handed one to Shinsou and one to Aizawa before digging into his own. Shinsou looked down at his full plate in surprise, unsure of what to do with so much food.


“We’re not going to send you to a group home,” Mic said around a mouth full of food. 


“I’ve cycled through all the foster homes around UA.”


“Not ours,” Aizawa said without thinking. He then froze, glancing over at Mic, who just smiled back at him.


“I was thinking the same thing,” he said. “We’ve got the space.”


“Wait, you’re saying I could stay here?”


“Sure, if you want to. That way you’ll still be close to UA. Good thing too, since you’ll be starting in the hero course soon.”


Shinsou blinked at Aizawa in confusion. “What are you talking about?”


“A spot is opening in my class. Nezu and I have agreed it's yours, if you still want it. So, Shinsou, do you still want to be a hero?”


“I… I do… more than anything.”


“Good. Then it's yours, as is the extra bedroom here.”

Bright and early the next morning, Aizawa, along with a social worker showed up at the Bakugou residence. A tall man with brown hair opened the door when they knocked. Somewhere behind the man, a screaming match was taking place between Bakugou and some woman.


Aizawa was reminded of the scene he’d stumbled on last night at Shinsou’s foster home.


“Hello, are you Bakugou-san?” Aizawa asked stiffly.


The man nodded. “Yes. May I ask who you are?”


“I’m Shota Aizawa, your son’s teacher. May we come in?”


Two hours later, Aizawa and the social worker were leaving, Bakugou and a set of suitcases in tow. 


While there hadn’t been any signs of extreme abuse like in Shinsou’s case, there was evidence of neglect. The Bakugous hadn’t cared about the sport festival incident, going as far as to say that “the brat” had deserved it. They let Bakugou run wild, only attempting to discipline the boy when he lashed out at them. On more than one occasion during the visit, Aizawa had heard Mitsuki Bakugou refer to her son as “weak” and degrade him and his quirk. Her husband had sat back quietly, not stepping in to agree with either his wife nor his son. He was just a passive bystander, watching everything unfold before him. Bakugou’s parents didn’t starve him, or lock him in closets, or muzzle him, but they never cooked for him, leaving him to fend for himself. They left enough money for him to buy food, or they would stock the kitchen, and then they would ignore him. 


Bakugou had admitted that his parents rarely spoke to him or checked to see where he was. They didn’t take him to the doctor after the incident with the slime villain, an incident that Aizawa knew hadn’t been included in Bakugou’s file. Bakugou begrudgingly laid out the story of his life, a lonely one filled with fear and confusion. Always being called weak by his parents, but strong by his teachers, he felt conflicted. Any time someone tried to show him genuine kindness, Bakugou would panic, thinking that if the person got close enough to him, they would realize how weak he was. So he pushed them away. He kept everyone at arm’s length. It was easier to be seen as aggressive rather than scared or weak. 


It wasn’t until he met Shinsou that he found someone he could trust, someone who 

understood

.


In the end, the social worker had told Bakugou’s parents that she had enough here to open a full investigation, which could easily damage their reputation and the reputation of their business. They’re options were to either go through with the investigation or to relinquish custody of Bakugou. 


They chose to give up custody.


While the social worker finalized the paperwork with Bakugou’s parents, Aizawa had helped Bakugou to pack his belongings, though the teen had decided to leave behind a number of things. Aizawa offered to come back later to get the rest of it, but Bakugou had just shrugged.


“Shinsou told me to trust you. Told me to let you help,” Bakugou had said quietly, looking down at his feet. “I listened to him.”


“I’m glad you did.”


“Where am I going to go?”


“The social worker will have to find you a foster home,” Aizawa said, sighing. “I will personally vet them and make sure it is safe. I can regularly check in too. I would offer to have you come stay with me, but Shinsou is already with us and we’re having to fight social services to be able to keep him. I don’t know if they’ll let us take in two kids, at least not at the same time like this.”


Bakugou scuffed one of his shoes against the floor, still not looking up. “What if I know someone I could stay with?”


“Who would that be?”


“Inko Midoriya. She was friends with my mom for a long time. But then I was an asshole to Dek- I mean, Izuku. Auntie had asked my mom to talk to me and teach me not to act like that and my mom basically said that it wasn’t a big deal and called Izuku weak. So Auntie stopped speaking to my mom. She… she might hate me. Same as Izuku. But I know her and trust her more than I trust a stranger. If she’s willing to take me, even if it's just for a night or two, I’d rather that than a foster home.”


Aizawa nodded. “Let me make some calls.”


He then left Bakugou inside to pack the last of his things and stepped out onto the front porch. It took him a moment to find the list of parents’ phone numbers that he kept on his phone, but eventually he found Midoriya-san’s number.


She answered right away, and when Aizawa briefly explained that Bakugou was being removed from his parents’ custody and had asked about possibly staying with her, she broke down crying.


“

That poor boy!

” she sobbed. “

He was so sweet when he was tiny, but as he got older, he grew so distant and cold! I should have known better! I should have said something to someone! Yes, bring him here! I’ll make space for him!

”


And so, when they left the Bakugou residence, they made their way to the Midoriya home. The social worker had gone into the dining room to discuss the process of fostering Bakugou to Midoriya-san while Aizawa sat with Bakugou and Izuku Midoriya in the living room.


“Boys,” Aizawa said sternly, “I understand there has been bad blood in the past between you two. I don’t know the specifics, but I need to know if Bakugou staying here is going to cause more issues between you guys.”


Midoriya immediately shook his head. “No! Mom explained everything and it kinda makes sense. Bakugou didn’t know how to make me leave him alone other than fighting with me, so I forgive him.”


Aizawa glanced at Bakugou, who had his head hung, hiding his face.


“You’re too forgiving, nerd,” Bakugou grumbled. “You should be angry. You should want me as far away from you as possible.”


“Well, I am still hurt you acted like that, but you didn’t really understand what you were doing, did you? And ever since the sports festival, you’ve been nicer and nicer to me, which I still don’t really understand.”


“The purple haired fucker you fought in the last event knocked some sense into me. Made me want to be a better person. And… fuck he’ll kill me if I don’t do this… Izuku, I’m sorry. I’m sorry for how I treated you. It was wrong.”


Midoriya’s eyes filled with tears as he lunged across the couch and latched onto Bakugou in a tight hug. “Kacchan! That was so nice!”


“Get off me!” Bakugou shouted, trying to shove Midoriya off while the green haired boy both laughed and cried tears of joy.


Looking at the two of them, Aizawa knew that things would work out in the end. It would take time, but they’d get there.


With Bakugou settled, Aizawa moved onto his list of teachers that he needed to have a word with. 


The first one on the list was All Might.


Aizawa smiled. He was going to enjoy this.

“Hitoshi?”


“Yeah?”


“Thanks.”
